awd_abstract_narration: Affine scaling methods form an important class of   point  algorithms for solving a linear programming problem,   and there  have been  some major developments in the convergence and  convergence   rate theory of these  methods.  In particular, when  the problem may be degenerate,   if the step size  is less than  equal to two thirds of the distance to the   boundary, the primal  converges to the interior of the optimal face, while the dual   to  the analytic  center of the optimal dual face.  Also, by a step  selection   strategy, these  methods have been shown to converge  superlinearly. More   efficient variants have  also been developed.  Under this project, four different   aspects of these  methods are being studied: 1) study of their convergence   properties, convergence  rates and complexity; 2) study of stable implementations to    achieve these  higher rates of convergence in computer  implementations; 3)   study of their  connection to Kalman filter  and their application to solving   stochastic linear  programming  problems; and, 4) study of their efficient   implementations in  vector/parallel/distributed computing environments.
